questions.text: Which cells are not present in the layer marked as D? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Langerhans cells

 

  • The layer marked as D is stratum basale.
  • Langerhan's cells are not present in stratum basale.
  • Langerhan's cells are predominantly present in stratum spinosum.
  • Keratinocytes, Merkel cells & Melanocytes are all seen in Stratum Basale.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratinocytes: Keratinocytes are the most prevalent cells in the epidermis and are definitely found in the stratum basale. They are responsible for the production of keratin, a key structural protein in the skin.

 

Option B. Merkel cells: Merkel cells are mechanoreceptor cells that are present in the basal layer of the epidermis. They are involved in the sensation of light touch.

 

Option C. Melanocytes: Melanocytes are also present in the stratum basale. These cells produce melanin, the pigment that gives skin its color and provides protection against UV radiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page no 2.4

questions.text: Which form of vitiligo is initially progressive and later becomes stable and non-progressive? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Segmental

 

  • Segmental vitiligo is a type of vitiligo that follows a dermatome or nerve segment.

 

 

  • It usually starts in early childhood and presents with depigmented macules or patches that are confined to one side of the body, following the distribution of a dermatome.
  • Segmental vitiligo progresses rapidly within the first 1-2 years, reaching its full extent, after which it becomes stable and non-progressive.
  • This type does not cross the midline and remains confined to the initial segmental area, making it distinct from other forms of vitiligo.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mixed: Mixed vitiligo involves both segmental and non-segmental vitiligo. Non-segmental vitiligo can continue to progress indefinitely, making this option incorrect for the description of a vitiligo type that becomes stable and non-progressive.

 

Option C. Acrofacial: Acrofacial vitiligo affects the distal parts of the body, such as the hands, feet, and face. This form of vitiligo can progress over time and does not become stable and non-progressive.

 

Option D. Focal: Focal vitiligo presents with one or a few isolated macules in a non-segmental distribution. Although it can remain localized, it does not specifically follow the pattern of being initially progressive and then becoming stable and non-progressive as segmental vitiligo does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Segmental vitiligo is characterized by its initial rapid progression confined to a segmental area, followed by stabilization and lack of further progression, distinguishing it from other forms of vitiligo that can remain progressive.

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with complaints of pain in his genital area. On examination, there were painful coalescing vesicles, associated with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes Simplex Virus-2 (HSV-2)

 

  • The clinical presentation of painful, coalescing vesicles which rupture to form polycyclic erosions along with painful lymphadenopathy is highly indicative of a Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV-2) infection.

 

 

  • HSV-2 primarily affects the genital area and is known for its recurrent, painful vesicular lesions.
  • The lymphadenopathy associated with HSV-2 is also typically painful, which aligns with the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum Contagiosum:

 

  • This is caused by a poxvirus and typically presents as small, firm, painless, umbilicated papules as shown below.

 

 

  • The key distinguishing feature here is the painless nature of the lesions, which does not correlate with the patient's painful vesicles and lymphadenopathy, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Option C. Human Papillomavirus (HPV):

 

  • HPV often leads to the development of warts (Condylomata) but these are generally painless and do not present as vesicles.

 

 

  • Additionally, HPV is less likely to cause significant lymphadenopathy, particularly painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV):

 

  • While VZV can cause painful vesicular lesions in the form of shingles (herpes zoster), these lesions are usually unilateral and follow a dermatomal distribution.

 

 

 

  • The genital involvement and bilateral lymphadenopathy are less characteristic of VZV reactivation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify Herpes Simplex Virus-2 (HSV-2) as the cause of painful, coalescing genital vesicles and painful lymphadenopathy in the given clinical scenario.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page 25.12, 25.16, 25.24, 25.44

questions.text: The most probable diagnosis for a young male presenting with Leucotrichia and lesions as depicted in the image is? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Segmental vitiligo

 

Localized, unilateral depigmented macules can be seen in the image. This characteristic and a history of leukotrichia point to the diagnosis of segmental vitiligo in the patient.

 

Vitiligo happens because the basal layer lacks melanocytes due to autoimmune destruction by auto antibodies.

 

The gradual loss of melanocytes causes a localized depigmentation to take place.

 

It is categorized as:

 

  1. Segmental vitiligo: This form of vitiligo is characterized by unilateral depigmented macules in a dermatomal or segmental pattern. The presence of Leucotrichia (white or colorless hair) within the lesion is a strong clinical indicator of segmental vitiligo. The image shows a pattern consistent with segmental vitiligo.
  2. Non-segmental vitiligo: which appears as bilateral macules distributed in an acrofacial pattern or scattered symmetrically over the entire body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal vitiligo: This is characterized by one or more macules or patches in one area without any recognizable pattern as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option C. Piebaldism: It is a rare autosomal dominant disorder that is present at birth. The hallmark of piebaldism is a white forelock as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The distribution of lesions is usually symmetrical and remains stable throughout life, which differs from the presentation in the image.

 

Option D. Nevus depigmentosus: This is a congenital, stable hypopigmented patch that does not progress or change with time. Unlike vitiligo, it does not show Leucotrichia, and the lesion does not spread.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Segmental vitiligo presents with one or more macules in a dermatomal or segmental pattern, often accompanied by Leucotrichia.

 

Ref - Rooks Textbook of dermatology 9th Edition page no 88.34

questions.text: The most common triggering factor of the given condition is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Infection

 

  • The given image shows characteristic target lesions of erythema multiforme (EMF)
  • Most common cause – Herpes simplex virus infection.

 

Erythema multiforme:

 

  • Self-limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from Type IV cell-mediated hypersensitivity.
  • It most commonly occurs following an infection with Herpes simplex virus infection.

 

Target lesions are less than 3 cm in diameter, rounded, and have three zones:

 

 

Location:

 

  • Palms and the trunk.
  • Oral and genital mucosal membranes lesions are associated with erosions.
  • It presents as the classic acral iris or 'Target lesions'.

 

The common triggers apart from Herpes simplex infection are:

 

  • Mycoplasma infection
  • Bacterial infections
  • Fungal infections
  • Vaccinations
  • Malignancy- carcinoma, lymphoma, leukemia
  • Drugs- sulphonamides, rifampicin, penicillin derivatives.

 

Note: Atypical target lesions with only 2 zones may be seen in Stevens Johnson syndrome (SJS) & Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drugs: While drugs can trigger EMF, they are not as commonly implicated as infections, especially HSV.

 

Option C. Vaccination: Vaccinations can occasionally trigger EMF but are less commonly a cause compared to infections.

 

Option D. Malignancy: Although malignancies can sometimes trigger EMF, they are much less common triggers compared to infections like HSV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common trigger for erythema multiforme, particularly when target lesions are present on the palms, is infection, notably with herpes simplex virus.

 

Additional information

 

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4. Page no 4.11, 4.13

Question Level – Intermediate 

Question Id-7462 Unique Key-Q3225777

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used as nail lacquer belongs to morpholines? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amorolfine

 

  • Amorolfine is a morpholine that is available as a 5% nail lacquer. Amorolfine inhibits two separate stages in the synthesis of ergosterol and is fungicidal.
  • It is used in the treatment of onychomycosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oxiconazole:

  • This is an azole antifungal drug.
  • Azoles work by inhibiting the enzyme lanosterol 14-α-demethylase, which is crucial in converting lanosterol to ergosterol.

 

Option C. Ciclopirox olamine:

  • Ciclopirox is a hydroxypyridone antifungal agent, not a morpholine.

 

 

  • It acts by chelating polyvalent cations, resulting in the inhibition of the metal-dependent enzymes responsible for the degradation of peroxides within fungal cells.

 

Option D. Tioconazole:

 

Tioconazole is another azole antifungal agent and, like oxiconazole, works by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amorolfine is the only morpholine derivative, used as a nail lacquer for the treatment of fungal infections.

 

Reference - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 18 Page no 18.12

Online resources: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20737634/

https://ijdvl.com/onychomycosis-diagnosis-and-management/

questions.text: A child presents to you with itchy lesions on the scalp with hair loss as shown in the image below. What would be the next best step? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) KOH mount

 

  • The image shows itchy lesions on the scalp with hair loss which is suggestive of a fungal infection, commonly tinea capitis.
  • The next best step in confirming the diagnosis would be to do a KOH mount.
  • The potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation is used to visualize fungal elements in skin, hair, and nail samples.
  • When applied, KOH dissolves the keratin in the skin, hair, and nails, leaving only fungal cells intact, which can then be visualized under the microscope.

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

  • Ectothrix - Spores & fungus present outside the hair shaft.
  • Endothrix - Spores & fungi present inside the hair shaft.

 

 

 

Kerion:

 

  • Presents in Children with boggy swelling, easily pluckable hair, with regional lymphadenopathy.
  • It is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis.
  • The most common causative organisms of kerion are Zoophilic dermatophytes, T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes. In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation.

 

 

Fig: Lesion: Boggy indurated scalp swelling

 

  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount
  • Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum is Griseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton is Terbinafine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Slit skin smear (SSS):

 

  • This is a procedure mainly used for diagnosing leprosy.
  • It involves taking a smear from the skin, usually from the earlobe, to look for acid-fast bacilli.
  • It is not appropriate in this case where fungal infection is suspected.

 

Option C. Gram staining:

 

  • This is a microbiological staining technique that is used to differentiate bacterial species into two large groups based on the chemical and physical properties of their cell walls.
  • It's not the first line of investigation for suspected fungal infections.

 

Option D. Biopsy:

 

  • While a biopsy can be used to diagnose various skin conditions, it is invasive and not the first line of investigation for a suspected fungal infection.
  • A KOH mount is a much simpler and direct test to confirm the presence of fungus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For itchy lesions on the scalp with hair loss suggestive of tinea capitis, a KOH mount is the preferred initial test to visualize fungal elements.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.38, 32.40

choices.text: Can occur in association with diabetes
Associated with sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s phenomenon
The dermis is 3-4 times thicker than normal
Erythema and peau d'orange appearance of the skin can be seen

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding scleredema?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Associated with sclerodactyly or Raynaud’s phenomenon.

 

Sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s Phenomenon are associated with Scleroderma (NOT with scleredema).

 

Scleredema & Scleroderma are different diseases.

 

 

Scleredema is not associated with sclerodactyly, Raynaud’s phenomenon, nail fold capillary changes or serum autoantibodies.

 

Scleredema:

Synonyms - Scleredema adultorum of Buschke, Scleredema Diabeticorum.

 

  • Scleredema results in taut skin with noticeable symmetrical, diffuse progressive, non-pitting induration. This is because the dermis has expanded, mucin has been deposited, and the subcutaneous fat has been replaced by coarse collagen fibers.
  • It commonly presents with erythema and induration on the posterior neck and back, along with a peau d'orange appearance of the skin. Interestingly, the hands and feet remain unaffected.
  • The condition is characterized by a 3-4 times thicker dermis than usual, caused by dysfunctional fibroblasts leading to increased type 1 collagen synthesis, but without fibroblast proliferation.

 

The most prevalent type of this condition is associated with diabetes mellitus, and it is more commonly found in men compared to other forms that are more frequently seen in women. The accumulation of collagen is attributed to irreversible glycosylation of collagen and its resistance to degradation by collagenase.

 

 

  • Against an erythematous backdrop, the image depicts scleredema in a diabetic patient with firm, non-pitting edema with induration on the upper back, neck, and shoulders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Can occur in association with diabetes: True, as scleredema is commonly associated with diabetes, where the glycosylation of collagen contributes to the pathology.

 

Option C. The dermis is 3-4 times thicker than normal: True, reflecting the histological changes in scleredema, including mucin deposition and increased type 1 collagen synthesis.

 

Option D. Erythema and peau d'orange appearance of the skin can be seen: True, these are characteristic cutaneous manifestations of scleredema, indicating the skin's texture and appearance changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Bolognia 4th edition, chapter 46, page no 870

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 59 page no 59.09 - 59.11.

Question Level – HARD

Question Id-7440 Unique Key-Q1728345

questions.text: Which of the following does not present with maculopapular rash? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zoster (shingles)

 

A maculopapular rash is not seen in zoster (shingles).

 

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution as shown in the image below.

 

 

Herpes zoster:

 

  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  1. Painful zoster infections in adults
  2. Facial zoster at any age
  3. Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rubella: Presents with a maculopapular rash as shown in the image below, which consists of minute, discrete macules.

 

 

  • The rash appears within 24 hours of onset of prodromal symptoms.

 

Option C. Dengue (during febrile phase): Dengue fever can present with a maculopapular rash during its febrile phase.

 

Option D. Measles: Measles is characterized by fever and a maculopapular skin rash, which is accompanied by immune clearance of measles virus (MV)-infected cells

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zoster (shingles) does not present with a maculopapular rash but rather with a painful, vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution. In contrast, rubella, dengue during the febrile phase, and measles are classic causes of maculopapular rashes.
 

 

Ref- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no. 25.27-25.28
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106
Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 4.13

questions.text: A child is presenting with the ptosis of the eye and the following presentation. What will be the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Capillary Hemangioma

 

Above image is showing capillary Hemangioma involving the left upper eyelid and periocular area.

 

It is a  most common tumor of the orbit and periorbital area in childhood.

 

Its benign in nature caused by the abnormal growth of blood vessels.

 

Types of hemangioma:

 

1. Capillary hemangioma (most common)

2. Juvenile/ strawberry hemangioma

3. Cavernous hemangioma

4. Pyogenic hemangioma.

 

Capillary hemangiomas can be small, solitary lesions or larger masses. They might lead to visual issues due to mechanical ptosis or associate with PHACE syndrome (posterior fossa anomalies, Hemangioma, Arterial lesions, Cardiac abnormalities, Eye or Endocrine abnormalities).

 

 30% of lesions resolved by the age of 3 years and 75% by the age of 7

 

Indications for treatment are:

 

  1. Visual amblyopia, astigmatism, occlusion strabismus
  2. Cosmetic
  3. Optic nerve compression
  4. Exposure keratopathy

 

Capillary Hemangioma regresses spontaneously very often.

 

Treatment options include:

 

  1. Beta blockers
  2. Steroids
  3. Interferon alpha 2A and vincristine
  4. Local resection with cutting cautery or carbon dioxide laser

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cavernous hemangioma

 

  • Features: These are deeper vascular malformations filled with blood. They can be found in deeper layers of the skin or even in organs and present as soft, blue-colored swellings as shown below.

 

 

  • Cavernous hemangiomas are deeper structures, and the clinical features provided specifically mention capillary hemangioma, which is more superficial.

 

Option C. Port wine stain

 

  • Features: Also known as nevus flammeus, it is a capillary malformation that presents as a flat, pink, red, or purplish mark. It remains unchanged throughout life and can be anywhere on the body but is often seen on the face as shown below in the image.

 

 

Option D. salmon patches or nevus simplex

 

  • Features: These are flat, pink patches that appear at birth. Commonly known as "stork bites" when on the neck and "angel kisses" when on the forehead or eyelids, they usually fade by the age of 2, especially those located on the forehead and eyelids.

 

Salmon patch

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnose capillary Hemangioma by recognizing a raised, bright red lesion on the skin, which can cause distortion of local structures, such as ptosis when it occurs on the eyelid.

 

References: Ghai essential pediatrics 9th edition- page no 679

Yanoff & Duker Textbook of Ophthalmology 5th Edition Page no 1327

Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10e Page no 518-520

questions.text: Identify this condition. (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Condyloma acuminata

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows anogenital warts, which are characteristic of condyloma acuminata. These warts are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV) and present as rough-surfaced papules and plaques in the anogenital region. The warts can vary in size and shape and are typically painless but can cause discomfort due to their location.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option  B. Herpes genitalis: This condition presents as grouped vesicles on an erythematous base. These vesicles can rupture to form polycyclic erosions.

 

 

Option  C. Condyloma lata: Associated with secondary syphilis, condyloma lata manifests as broad-based, moist, eroded, flat papules and plaques in the genital area.

 

 

Option  D. Hemorrhoids: These are swollen and inflamed veins in the rectum and anus, presenting as bluish swollen lumps that can cause pain and bleeding. The image does not depict the typical appearance of hemorrhoids.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Condyloma acuminata presents as rough-surfaced papules and plaques in the anogenital area, characteristic of anogenital warts caused by HPV. Recognizing the appearance of these lesions is crucial for diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with a satellite skin lesion. On examination, the patient has one hypopigmented lesion and one thickened nerve. The images of two blister packs are provided. Based on the WHO / NLEP Guidelines, which treatment is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer:

The correct answer is B. Packet 2 for 12 months.

Latest Guidelines for Leprosy: NLEP = WHO (from April 1, 2025)

As of April 1, 2025, India's NLEP has aligned completely with WHO guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of leprosy. This means that the same criteria and drug regimens are now followed globally and in India.

 

*If a case has any one of the three features suggestive of MB, he/she is classified as MB.

 

Treatment Regimen: WHO & NLEP (Post April 1st 2025)

 

Other Options:

Option A: Packet 1 for 12 months: 

This packet was used for the treatment of paucibacillary leprosy according to old guidelines of NLEP, which is not suitable for a patient with multibacillary leprosy.

Option C: Packet 1 for 6 months: 

This packet was used for the treatment of paucibacillary leprosy according to old guidelines of NLEP, which is not suitable for a patient with multibacillary leprosy.

Option D Packet 2 for 6 months: 

Although Packet 2 contains the correct medications, the treatment duration of 6 months is insufficient for multibacillary leprosy according to WHO guidelines, which recommends 12 months.

 

OLD NLEP GUIDELINES to diagnose Leprosy 

OLD NLEP GUIDELINES to treat Leprosy 

OLD PB MDT with 2 drugs followed by NLEP:

 

Educational objective:

  • As of April 1, 2025, NLEP follows WHO guidelines for both diagnosis and treatment.
  • Classification is based on skin lesions, nerve involvement, and skin smear.
  • For a patient with multibacillary leprosy, characterized by one or more thickened nerves and multiple skin lesions, the appropriate treatment is with a regimen containing rifampicin, clofazimine, and dapsone (Packet 2) for a duration of 12 months.

 

References:

Jopling’s handbook of leprosy, 6th edition, page no 10

Andrew’s diseases of the skin: clinical dermatology 13th edition page no 338, 339, 345

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of this condition affecting hair? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trichothiodystrophy

 

The given clinical image of hair seen under polarizing microscopy reveals tiger tail banding (alternating light and dark bands) characteristic of trichothiodystrophy.

 

Trichothiodystrophy/PIBIDS syndrome: Autosomal Recessive condition

 

  • Photosensitivity (unlike XP, has NO increased skin cancer risk)
  • Ichthyosis
  • Brittle hair (short/sparse on scalp/brows/lashes w/alternating light and dark bands on polarizing light microscopy (“tiger-tail” abnormality)
  • Intellectual impairment and ataxia
  • Decreased fertility/hypogonadism
  • Short stature

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichorrhexis nodosa: It is associated with node formation. It may be seen in arginosuccinic aciduria. Characterized by classical appearance as if two paint brushes are rubbing against each other described as Thrust Paintbrush appearance.

 

 

Option B. Trichorrhexis invaginata: Also known as Bamboo hair having Golf tee or Ball & Socket appearance, is characterized by invagination of the distal hair shaft into the proximal portion. Seen in Netherton’s syndrome.

 

 

Option D: Monilethrix: Beaded hair seen in Menkes disease.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Tiger tail" banding of hair under polarized light microscopy is indicative of trichothiodystrophy, a condition characterized by brittle hair with reduced sulfur content and potentially associated with multisystem involvement.

 

Ref - Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page no 1537

Rooks Textbook of dermatology 9th edition Volume III Pages 68.19, 78.10 89.53-54

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 35-year-old patient who has presented with easily rupturing flaccid bulla on the skin and whose biopsy indicates a suprabasal split?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • Based on the clinical presentation of bullous lesions and the histologic finding of a suprabasal blister, Pemphigus vulgaris is suspected.
  • This condition involves the production of antibodies, particularly against Desmoglein 3, and sometimes Desmoglein 1. These antibodies are typically of the IgG type. Desmoglein 3 is primarily found in the basal and suprabasal layers of the skin and mucosa.
  • As a result, patients exhibit flaccid bullae on the skin, and mucosal involvement, especially in the oral mucosa, is common.

 

 

  • Ulceration may also occur in other areas such as the conjunctiva, nasopharynx, and larynx. Cutaneous lesions are more frequently observed on the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus Vegetans:

  • Description: Pemphigus vegetans is a variant of pemphigus vulgaris. It features vesicles and bullae that evolve into verrucous (wart-like) lesions, particularly in skin folds.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The primary presentation in the question doesn't describe verrucous or wart-like lesions.

 

Option C. Pemphigus foliaceus:

  • Description: Pemphigus foliaceus is another type of pemphigus but is characterized by more superficial skin blisters than pemphigus vulgaris, and it doesn't typically involve the mucous membranes.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The biopsy of pemphigus foliaceus would show a split in the upper epidermis (subcorneal), not a suprabasal split.

 

Option D. Erythema multiforme:

  • Description: Erythema multiforme is an acute, immune-mediated skin condition. It is characterized by target-like lesions and is often triggered by infections (e.g., herpes simplex virus) or certain medications.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The presentation of erythema multiforme is quite distinct with its target-like lesions, and a biopsy would not reveal a suprabasal split.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is identified by the presence of flaccid bullae that rupture easily and a suprabasal split on biopsy, indicating an autoimmune process causing loss of epidermal cell adhesion.

 

 

Reference: 

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page no 47.1-47.5, 50.1-50.10

Online resources:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3884912/

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17619399/

questions.text:
Which diagnostic investigation is utilized to identify the condition characterized by a 40-year-old man displaying abrupt erythematous painful lesions on the trunk and face, joint pain, and glove and stock anesthesia? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Nerve examination
  2. Skin biopsy
  3. Slit skin smear
  4. Mantoux test
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

The clinical scenario points to a case of leprosy. The diagnosis of this condition requires nerve examination, skin biopsy, and a slit skin smear (option B - 1, 2, 3).

 

The clinical presentation described suggests a condition called leprosy or Hansen's disease, which can cause skin lesions, nerve damage resulting in anaesthesia, and joint pain.

 

1. Nerve examination: An essential part of the diagnosis of leprosy involves the examination of nerves for enlargement and tenderness, which can indicate nerve damage due to the disease.

 

2. Skin biopsy: A biopsy of the affected skin can be taken and histologically examined for the presence of Mycobacterium leprae, the bacterium that causes leprosy.

 

3. Slit skin smear:  This test involves taking a sample from the skin (usually from the earlobes or from lesions) and staining it for acid-fast bacilli, which is a characteristic of Mycobacterium leprae.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Mantoux test:

 

  • The Mantoux test is used to diagnose tuberculosis, not leprosy.
  • It involves the tuberculin skin test (TST) to detect Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Mycobacterium leprae are both acid-fast bacilli.
  • The Mantoux test is specific for TB and does not directly aid in the diagnosis of leprosy

 

Characteristic clinical features of Hansen’s disease / Leprosy

 

  • Mycobacterium leprae is the cause of the chronic granulomatous disease known as leprosy.
  • The typical incubation period for leprosy is 2 to 12 years.
  • It frequently manifests as a visible skin lesion, such as a hypopigmented or erythematous macule, or as a numb spot on the skin.
  • The face, buttocks, trunk, and extensor aspects of the limbs are frequently affected by lesions.
  • Skin, cutaneous, and peripheral nerves, as well as mucous membranes, are all impacted.
  • The posterior tibial nerve, followed by the ulnar, median, and lateral popliteal nerves, are the peripheral nerves that are most frequently affected.
  • The facial nerve is the cranial nerve that is involved most frequently.
  • Both nerve function and hair growth are compromised by the lesions.
  • Burns or ulcers on the amputation limb may also be present in the patients.

 

Additional Information

 

Classification systems of leprosy:

 

Ridley-Jopling classification

 

  • Tuberculoid (TT)
  • Borderline tubercular (BT)
  • Borderline (BB)
  • Borderline lepromatous (BL)
  • Lepromatous (LL)

 

WHO classification:

 

  • Paucibacillary
  • Multibacillary

 

Cardinal signs for the diagnosis of leprosy:

 

 

  • The presence of two of the three signs can establish the diagnosis of leprosy. Other tests done for diagnosis of leprosy include nerve biopsy in pure neural leprosy and PGL-1 antibody in cases with low bacterial load.
  • Mantoux test is not useful in diagnosis of leprosy. This is the test which helps to explain the prognosis of leprosy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate diagnostic investigations for a suspected case of leprosy include nerve examination, skin biopsy, and slit skin smear to detect the presence of Mycobacterium leprae and to assess the extent of nerve damage.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 28 page no 28.1, 28.3, 28.12

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine, 21st edition 1385, 1386, 1388

questions.text: A rose gardener with a history of thorn prick presents with the following lesions. What is the possible causative agent? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sporothrix schenckii

 

Diagnosis from the given findings is Sporotrichosis.

 

Few important points about Sporotrichosis:

 

  • Caused by Sporothrix schenckii
  • An acute or chronic fungal infection where, a linear distribution of nodules is seen Commonly in gardeners, florists due to high thorn prick possibility.

 

Clinically presents with Linear nodulo-ulcerative lesions (Sporotrichoid) aligned along lymphatics, with Satellite lesions.

 

Sporotrichoid lesions also seen in:

 

  • Fish tank/Swimming pool granuloma
  • Lupus vulgaris.

 

The given image shows the distribution of lesions along lymphatics.

 

 

Histopathology: Asteroid bodies are seen as shown in the image below.

 

 

Treatment: Itraconazole / Terbinafine / Saturated solution of Potassium Iodide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pyogenes:

 

  • While Streptococcus pyogenes can cause skin infections, it is not typically associated with thorn pricks or rose gardening.
  • This bacterium is more commonly linked with pharyngitis, scarlet fever, and rheumatic fever.

 

Option C. Strongyloides stercoralis:

 

  • This is an intestinal nematode and is not associated with skin lesions from thorn pricks.
  • It primarily causes gastrointestinal symptoms and can cause systemic disease in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus:

 

  • This bacterium can indeed cause skin infections, but the scenario described is not its classic presentation.
  • Staphylococcus aureus can take advantage of wounds to cause infection, but it is not specifically associated with thorn pricks or rose gardening

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a history of thorn prick, especially a gardener, presenting with nodular lesions along lymphatic channels, the most likely causative agent is Sporothrix schenckii, responsible for sporotrichosis, a fungal infection commonly associated with gardening activities.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition, Chapter 32 Page no 32.71

Illustrated synopsis of dermatology & sexually transmitted diseases page no 297

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine, 21st edition Page no 1542

questions.text: Which of the following drugs in leprosy treatment cause hyperpigmentation? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clofazimine

 

Explanation:

 

  • Clofazimine is an antimicrobial agent used primarily in the treatment of leprosy.
  • One of the notable side effects of clofazimine is skin pigmentation changes, which can manifest as hyperpigmentation.
  • This occurs because clofazimine accumulates in the skin, leading to discoloration.
  • The pigmentation typically appears as a reddish or brownish coloration and can be distressing for patients due to its noticeable cosmetic impact.
  • The pigmentation is long-lasting and may take several months to years to fade after discontinuation of the drug.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dapsone: Dapsone is another drug used in the treatment of leprosy, but it does not cause hyperpigmentation. Its side effects include hemolysis and methemoglobinemia, especially in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

 

Option B. Ofloxacin: Ofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic used to treat various bacterial infections, including leprosy, but it is not associated with hyperpigmentation. Its common side effects include gastrointestinal disturbances and tendonitis.

 

Option C. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is an antibiotic used to treat several bacterial infections, including leprosy. It can cause reddish-orange discoloration of bodily fluids like urine, sweat, and tears but does not cause hyperpigmentation of the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clofazimine is a drug used in leprosy treatment that can cause significant and long-lasting hyperpigmentation of the skin.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 38-year-old female who is experiencing substantial hair loss for 4 months and has a history of COVID-19 infection 8 months ago? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Telogen effluvium

 

  • The pattern of hair loss in this clinical scenario is telogen effluvium.
  • The condition described is characterized by the sudden onset of scalp hair loss, typically occurring one to two months after a triggering event, which may include high fever, infections (such as Cholera, Typhoid, or COVID-19), surgery, trauma, starvation, myocardial infarction (MI), pregnancy, or hemorrhage.
  • This type of hair loss is associated with an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to the premature termination of the anagen proliferative phase of the hair cycle following a period of significant stress.
  • When telogen hair shedding lasts for more than six months, it is termed “chronic diffuse telogen hair loss.” The main causes of chronic diffuse telogen hair loss include thyroid conditions (both hyper- and hypothyroidism), severe iron deficiency anemia, acrodermatitis enteropathica, and malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Androgenetic alopecia: Typically presents as a patterned hair loss and is more gradual. It is driven by genetic factors and hormonal influences and does not usually have a sudden onset associated with illness.

 

Option C. Alopecia areata:

  • An autoimmune condition where the body's immune system attacks hair follicles.
  • It results in small, round, and smooth patches of hair loss, which can coalesce but often do not cause complete hair loss.

 

 

  • It's not directly linked to illnesses like COVID-19 and does not typically present as diffuse hair loss across the entire scalp as suggested in the question.

 

Option D. Trichotillomania:

  • A psychological condition where individuals compulsively pull out their own hair, leading to hair loss.
  • Hair loss pattern tends to be irregular with varied length hairs, and examination often reveals broken hairs.

 

 

 

  • The history provided does not suggest any compulsive behavior or the typical patchy, irregular pattern seen with trichotillomania.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Telogen effluvium is a form of non-scarring hair loss characterized by the diffuse shedding of hair resulting from the early entry of hair into the telogen phase (the resting phase of the hair cycle). This condition is often triggered by significant physiological stress, severe illness, or major life events.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 89 page no 32.24, 32.39, 32.40, 86.17, 89.6, 89.14, 89.17, 89.20 89.24, 89.25, 89.46

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page 1509

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition 387

questions.text: Match the wood lamp findings with the respective diseases: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-e,2-c,3-d,4-b

 

Erythrasma (1-e): Shows a characteristic coral red fluorescence under Wood's lamp. This fluorescence is due to the production of porphyrins by Corynebacterium minutissimum, the bacteria responsible for erythrasma.

 

Pityriasis versicolor (2-c): Typically displays a yellow fluorescence. The causative yeast, Malassezia, can produce metabolites that fluoresce under a Wood's lamp.

 

Tinea Capitis (3-d): Often shows a blue fluorescence. The fungi causing tinea capitis, like species of Microsporum, can fluoresce blue due to the presence of certain metabolic byproducts in the fungal cell walls.

 

Vitiligo (4-b): Exhibits a milky white fluorescence. This is because the areas affected by vitiligo lack melanin, making the skin appear distinctly brighter under the UV light of a Wood's lamp compared to normal skin.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Wood's lamp is a useful diagnostic tool in dermatology for visualizing certain fungal and bacterial infections, as well as pigmentary disorders. The specific color of fluorescence can guide clinicians in making a preliminary diagnosis, which must be confirmed with additional tests or clinical evaluation.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a child who has asymptomatic lesions on the forearm and shaft of the penis, lesions on the shaft of penis are as shown below? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lichen nitidus

 

The image shows an aggregate of skin colored papules over the shaft of penis of a child which is suggestive of lichen nitidus.

 

  • Lichen nitidus most frequently affects children or young adults.
  • The dorsum of the forearms or penis is where Lichen Nitidus most commonly manifests as tiny pinhead-sized flesh-colored papules. In early lesions, Lichen Nitidus and Lichen planus share a similar histological profile. Mucous membrane involvement is quite rare in lichen nitidus. True Koebner’s phenomenon is evident.
  • Lesions are self-limiting & no treatment is required.

 

 

Above Image depicts lichen nitidus over elbow with True Koebner’s phenomenon seen.

 

  • As both LP and Lichen Nitidus share a similar histological profile in early lesions, they are both regarded as variants of LP.
  • Claw clutching Ball appearance: The Ball is comprised of well circumscribed granulomatous infiltrate of lymphocytes, epithelioid cells & occasional Langhan’s giant cells that are clutched by surrounding hyperplastic rete ridges, giving the overall claw clutching ball appearance.
  • Lesions are typically asymptomatic and infrequently need medical attention.
  • The histology of Lichen Nitidus is shown in the image below, where a well-defined granuloma is surrounded by rete pegs and appears to be claw clutching a ball.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichen planus: This condition often presents as purplish, flat-topped bumps as shown in the image below, these lesions can be itchy. The lesions can also affect mucosal surfaces forming white lacy / reticulate pattern. The described presentation and the image provided do not align with this diagnosis.

 

 

Option C. Scrofuloderma: It is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis which results from the direct invasion of the tubercle bacillus into the skin from underlying tuberculous foci.

 

  • It typically presents as cold abscesses, ulcers, or nodules as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option D. Scabies: This parasitic infection presents with intense itching.

 

  • The burrows of the mite may be seen on the skin, typically in the interdigital spaces.
  • The lesions in the image do not match the typical appearance of scabies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lichen nitidus is a probable diagnosis in a child with asymptomatic lesions on the forearm and genitalia, especially when the lesions appear as tiny, flesh-colored bumps.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 37 page no 37.3, 37.10, 37.11, 37.39

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition Page no 554

questions.text: In a 45-year-old male patient from Bihar with a normo-anesthetic hypopigmented lesion and a history of prolonged fever in childhood, what is the probable clinical diagnosis, considering the absence of thickened nerves?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Post kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis

 

The case scenario suggests a diagnosis of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis.

 

Occurs 1-5 years after Kala azar in untreated or incompletely treated cases. Manifests as nodules over exposed areas (Face), Hypopigmented macules over trunk and photosensitivity.

 

The rash is progressive over many years and seldom heals spontaneously.

 

 

Important differential for PKDL is Lepromatous leprosy:

 

 

Drug of choice for:

 

  • Kala azar - Liposomal Amphotericin B
  • PKDL - Miltefosine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculoid leprosy:

 

  • This form of leprosy presents with hypopigmented patches with well-defined borders.
  • However, it is typically associated with thickened nerves, which is absent in the patient described.

 

Option B. Lepromatous leprosy:

 

  • This is a more advanced and disseminated form of leprosy with multiple nodules, plaques, and thickened nerves.
  • It doesn't fit the presentation described.

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides:

 

It is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. The initial presentation can be patches, which might resemble the described lesions, but the history of prolonged fever in childhood and the geographic location (Bihar) make PKDL more probable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PKDL is a probable diagnosis in a patient with a history of prolonged fever in childhood presenting with normo-anesthetic hypopigmented lesions without any thickened nerves, especially from the Bihar region.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 33 page no 33.50-33.51, 140.10

questions.text: Treatment of this condition in a pregnant female would be? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cryotherapy

 

Explanation:

 

The condition shown in the image is condyloma acuminatum, also known as genital warts, caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV).

 

In pregnant females, the treatment options are limited due to potential teratogenic effects of certain medications. Cryotherapy is considered safe and effective for treating genital warts during pregnancy. If cryotherapy is not an option, trichloroacetic acid can also be used safely.

 

If the women is not Pregnant then Podophyllin can be given

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Podophyllin: This medication is teratogenic and should be avoided in pregnant women.

 

Option B. Imiquimod: Safety studies on the use of imiquimod during pregnancy are lacking, so it is also avoided in pregnant females.

 

Option D. Surgical excision: This is generally reserved for very large genital warts, such as Buschke-Löwenstein tumors, and is not the first-line treatment for typical cases of condyloma acuminatum in pregnant females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant females with condyloma acuminatum, cryotherapy is the preferred treatment due to its safety profile, while teratogenic treatments like podophyllin and those with uncertain safety like imiquimod should be avoided.

questions.text: A patient presents with following lesions on the genitals. Scrapings from the lesion would show? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both A & B

 

Tzanck cells & MNGCs can be seen in Herpes lesions.

 

The provided image displays clusters of vesicles on an erythematous base, indicative of a possible diagnosis of genital herpes caused by Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.

 

Tzanck smear:

 

  • To perform a Tzanck smear, scrapings are obtained from the lesions, preferably from the base of the vesicles.
  • Smears are then prepared and stained with a 1% aqueous solution of O-toluidine blue for 15 seconds, which allows the visualization of acantholytic and multinucleated giant cells.
  • In Herpes infections, Tzanck smear examination may reveal the presence of Tzanck cells and multinucleated giant cells.

 

Below image depicts Acantholytic cells

 

 

Below image depicts multinucleated giant cells

 

 

  • Tzanck or Acantholytic cells are formed as a result of acantholysis, which is the breakdown of intercellular connections, like desmosomes.
  • This process leads to a reduction in cohesiveness among keratinocytes.

 

Acantholysis is classified as:

 

 

Other Option:

 

Option D. Henderson Patterson bodies:

 

  • These are intracytoplasmic inclusions seen in cells infected with molluscum contagiosum, a skin infection caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus.
  • This is not consistent with the lesion shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Herpes simplex virus infections, scrapings from lesions may show both Acantholytic / Tzanck cells and Multinucleate giant cells (MNGCs).

 

Ref - Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 474-476

questions.text: A drug used to treat Tinea cruris that is experiencing an increasing development of widespread resistance is? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Terbinafine

 

  • Terbinafine is an antifungal used to treat Tinea cruris ("Jock/Dhobi itch").
  • Tinea cruris is typically caused by the fungus Trichophyton rubrum.
  • Effectiveness of terbinafine is compromised due to increasing resistance, especially in chronic or recurrent infections.
  • Resistance to terbinafine is associated with mutations in the squalene epoxidase gene, diminishing the drug’s efficacy.

 

 

  • Squalene epoxidase is vital for ergosterol synthesis, crucial for the fungal cell membrane.
  • Terbinafine-resistant fungal strains are cross-resistant to other squalene epoxidase inhibitors.

 

NOTE: Despite resistance to terbinafine, these strains remain sensitive to azoles and other antifungal classes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Itraconazole:

 

  • While Itraconazole is effective against dermatophytoses, but there's no specific indication of increasing resistance against it in the context of Tinea cruris.
  • Mechanism of Action: Itraconazole inhibits the enzyme cytochrome P450 14α-demethylase, which is necessary for the conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane. This leads to accumulation of toxic intermediates and membrane dysfunction.

 

Option B. Griseofulvin:

 

  • This drug is used for treatment, but there's no specific indication of increasing resistance against it in the context of Tinea cruris.
  • Mechanism of Action: Griseofulvin binds to tubulin, disrupting the microtubule function and thereby inhibiting mitosis in fungal cells. It specifically targets dividing fungal cells.

 

Option D. Voriconazole:

 

  • Mechanism of Action: Similar to Itraconazole, Voriconazole also inhibits the cytochrome P450 enzyme involved in the production of ergosterol for the fungal cell membrane.
  • It has a broad spectrum of antifungal activity. But it is not routinely used for treating superficial fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Terbinafine is increasingly encountering resistance in the treatment of Tinea cruris, likely due to mutations in the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase, which is the drug's target.

 

Online source:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC148991 HYPERLINK "https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC148991/"/
