ncbi.nlm.nih.gov - Update on terbinafine with a focus on dermatophytoses

[ijdvl.com - III. Antifungal resistance and treatment options https://ijdvl.com/the-unprecedented-epidemic-like-scenario-of-dermatophytosis-in-india-iii-antifungal-resistance-and-treatment-options/

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a patient who presents with flaccid bullous lesions affecting both the oral cavity and the skin, as shown in the provided image, and exhibits acantholytic cells on Tzanck smear? (AIIMS May 2019
questions.solution:
Ans B) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

Flaccid lesions, mucosal involvement, and the presence of acantholytic cells are suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris.

 

The production of antibodies, specifically those against Desmoglein 3, is seen in Pemphigus vulgaris. Desmoglein 1 antibodies are also occasionally associated. Usually, the antibodies are IgG antibodies. The skin and mucosa's basal and suprabasal layers contain the majority of Desmoglein 3.

 

The patients, therefore, present with flaccid bullae over the skin and due to Desmoglein 3 involvement, mucosal involvement can also be seen. Oral mucosa is commonly affected. Other areas where ulceration can be seen are conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, etc.

 

Cutaneous lesions are more common over the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus foliaceus: Autoantibodies are seen against only Desmoglein 1, not against DsG 3, so there is no mucosal involvement in pemphigus foliaceus.

 

Option C. Dermatitis herpetiformis presents with multiple small Papulo-vesicles, which are extremely itchy and it is a subepidermal blistering disorder, so acantholysis will not be seen.

 

Option D. Bullous Pemphigoid presents as Tense bullae, which can have an erythematous base (urticarial wheals) & it is a subepidermal blistering disorder, so acantholysis will not be seen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of flaccid bullous lesions affecting both the oral cavity and the skin, along with the observation of acantholytic cells on a Tzanck smear, is most consistent with a diagnosis of pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 50 Page no 50.1-50.8

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 356

questions.text: What type of connective tissue is found in the region indicated by the black arrow in the provided image? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dense irregular

 

In the provided image, the black arrow points to a region with a meshwork of collagen fibers. This pattern is characteristic of dense irregular connective tissue, which is identified by its densely packed collagen fibers that are arranged in an irregular, haphazard fashion. This type of connective tissue provides strength and support and allows the skin to resist multidirectional forces. It is typically found in areas that require strength and rigidity, such as the dermis of the skin, which is what is likely being shown in this histological slide.

 

Dermis (precisely Reticular dermis) is made up of dense irregular connective tissue.

 

Irregular connective tissue, is characterized by collagen fibers that are randomly oriented in multiple directions.

 

Irregular connective tissue is of three types: Loose, Dense & Adipose.

 

Dense connective tissue can be found in areas where unsheathed organs are protected and where there is significant mechanical stress.

 

  • This arrangement of fibers provides strength and elasticity in multiple directions, allowing the skin to resist tearing.

 

Function: Provides structural integrity and support for the skin.

 

Dense connective tissue:

 

  • It typically exists in the reticular dermis.
  • Muscle and nerve sheaths made of the superficial connective tissue
  • Adventitia of large vessels
  • Capsules of various organs & glands (e.g.: testis sclera, periosteum, perichondrium)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dense regular connective tissue features collagen fibers that are parallel to each other, conferring tensile strength in one particular direction. It is typically found in tendons and ligaments, where the force is exerted in a single direction as shown in the image below.

 

 

This is not what we see in the image, where the fibers are not arranged in parallel.

 

Irregular and Regular connective tissue

 

 

Option C. Loose regular connective tissue is not a recognized classification.

 

Option D. Loose irregular connective tissue is also not a recognized classification. What is commonly known is loose connective tissue (also termed areolar connective tissue), which has a much looser fiber arrangement and a lot of ground substance, often found beneath epithelial layers, surrounding blood vessels, and nerves. It has a different appearance from what is indicated by the arrow in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The image shows dense irregular connective tissue, which is characterized by a dense network of collagen fibers arranged in an irregular pattern, commonly found in the dermis of the skin, providing strength and the ability to resist multi-directional forces.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page no 2.34

Grays Anatomy: The anatomical basis of clinical practice- 42nd edition- page no 40, 41

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with the clinical condition shown in the image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Malignant Melanoma

 

The given image showing a benign proliferation of Nevus (type of melanocytes) in a child points to diagnosis of congenital melanocytic nevus.

 

Characteristics of Congenital Melanocytic Nevus

 

  • Seen since birth
  • Black-colored palpable lesion with well-defined borders
  • Surface is rough, hair
  • If > 20cm – giant congenital melanocytic nevus
  • Risk of melanoma is present

 

Congenital melanocytic nevi (CMN) can be associated with various complications, some of which include:

 

  1. Risk of Melanoma: Individuals with CMN have an increased risk of developing melanoma, a type of skin cancer. This risk is particularly higher in cases of giant congenital melanocytic nevi (GCMN)
  2. Neurocutaneous Melanosis: CMN can be linked to neurocutaneous melanosis, a condition where melanocytes are found in the central nervous system. This condition can lead to neurological issues and requires careful monitoring and management
  3. Proliferative Nodules: In some cases, CMN may develop proliferative nodules, which are areas of increased pigmentation and growth within the nevus. These nodules should be evaluated by a healthcare professional to rule out malignancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cataract: This is characterized by clouding of the lens within the eye, leading to a decrease in vision. It is not related to skin lesions such as a congenital melanocytic nevus.

 

Option B: Sturge-Weber Syndrome (SWS) often leads to secondary glaucoma due to vascular malformations affecting eye drainage, with facial involvement increasing the risk.

 

SWS presents clinically as Port wine stain.

 

Port wine stain

 

  • Features: Also known as nevus flammeus, it is a capillary malformation that presents as a flat, pink, red, or purplish mark. It remains unchanged throughout life and can be anywhere on the body but is often seen on the face as shown below in the image.

 

 

Managing SWS-related glaucoma requires a multidisciplinary approach and regular eye exams for early detection and vision preservation.

 

Option D. Basal cell carcinoma: This is the most common form of skin cancer, often associated with long-term sun exposure. It typically appears as a raised, pearly bump and does not usually develop from congenital melanocytic nevi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Congenital melanocytic nevi, especially larger ones, carry an increased risk for the development of malignant melanoma.
  • Monitoring and possibly biopsy of suspicious changes within these nevi are important for early detection of malignant transformation.

 

References: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page number 75.9 to 75.14 73.2, 73.3

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a young man who has presented with painful lesions, as depicted in the image below? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes Zoster

 

  • The above image shows confluent, red, vesicular lesions in a single dermatome which is associated with severe pain; hence the most likely diagnosis here would be herpes zoster or shingles.
  • Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution.
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection, but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  • Painful zoster infections in adults
  • Facial zoster at any age
  • Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum contagiosum: This is a viral infection of the skin that causes small, pearly, or flesh-coloured bumps. The lesions are typically umbilicated, meaning they have a small indentation or dimple at the centre as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option C. Herpes Simplex: It presents as grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, usually around the lips or genital region as shown in the image below. It does not follow a dermatomal pattern.

 

 

Option D. Lymphangioma circumscriptum: This condition presents as vesicles filled with lymphatic fluid as shown in the image below. It typically does not have the painful, dermatomal distribution seen in herpes zoster.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ability to recognize Herpes Zoster by its characteristic painful, vesicular rash in a unilateral dermatomal distribution.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page nos 4.13, 25.27-25.28, 109.36, 128.2,

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in image below? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Congenital melanocytic nevus

 

The Picture shown above depicts a child with a well circumscribed, black, heterogenous lesion covered with hair. This is a characteristic lesion of congenital melanocytic nevus (CMN).

 

CMNs are benign proliferations of nevus cells that are present at birth or develop shortly after. They are known for their variable pigmentation and the presence of terminal hair.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidermal verrucous nevus:

 

  • Description: A type of epidermal nevus (skin lesion) that is characterized by a warty or rough appearance as seen in the below image.

 

 

  • Why it's not the answer: While these can be present at birth or appear later in life, they don't typically present as deeply pigmented lesions with dense hair.

 

Option C. Melanoacanthoma:

 

  • Description: A rare, benign skin lesion that typically presents as a rapidly growing, hyperpigmented patch or plaque as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • It has a combination of melanocytes and keratinocytes.
  • Why it's not the answer: Although melanoacanthomas are pigmented lesions, they don't typically have dense hair growth, making it less consistent with the provided description.

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma:

 

  • Description: A type of skin cancer that arises from melanocytes. It can appear as a new, irregularly-shaped mole with uneven color or a mole that changes in size, shape, or color.
  • Why it's not the answer: While malignant melanoma is a pigmented lesion, the hallmark features include asymmetry, border irregularity, color variation, and diameter enlargement (often referred to by the mnemonic ABCD) as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • The presence of dense hair is not a characteristic feature of melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Melanocytic Nevus (CMN):

 

  • Presentation: These nevi are typically pigmented and hairy and may vary in size. The presence of hair is a distinguishing feature that often helps differentiate them from other pigmented lesions.
  • Risk Factors: Larger nevi have a higher risk of developing malignant melanoma later in life, but this is rare with smaller nevi.
  • Management: Monitoring is essential, and in some cases, surgical removal may be considered for aesthetic reasons or to reduce melanoma risk, particularly in larger lesions.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 75 Page no 75.14

questions.text: The farmer presents with a cauliflower-like mass on the foot, which developed after a minor injury, as depicted in the image. Microscopic examination reveals the presence of copper penny bodies. Based on this information, what is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chromoblastomycosis

 

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is chromoblastomycosis.

 

Chromoblastomycosis:

 

  • Causative Organism:  Fonsecaea, Cladophialophora species.
  • Clinical features: The initial presentation consists of warty papules that gradually enlarge, forming a hypertrophic plaque resembling cauliflower. Over the course of months to years, these lesions progress to large, hyperkeratotic masses with a surface often speckled with black dots.

 

 

Histopathology: Foreign body granuloma & Sclerotic / Medlar / Copper penny /Muriform bodies.

 

Treatment: Itraconazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blastomycosis:

  • Caused by the fungus Blastomyces dermatitidis.
  • It primarily affects the lungs but can spread to other parts of the body, including the skin.
  • Skin manifestations can be ulcerative or verrucous but the presence of "copper penny bodies" is not a characteristic feature of this infection.
  • Thus, the microscopic finding does not match this option.

 

Option C. Sporotrichosis/Rose Gardeners disease.

Few important points about Sporotrichosis:

  • Caused by Sporothrix schenckii
  • An acute or chronic fungal infection where, a linear distribution of nodules is seen Commonly in gardeners, florists due to high thorn prick possibility.

 

Clinically presents with Linear noduloulcerative lesions (Sporotrichoid) aligned along lymphatics, with Satellite lesions.

 

Sporotrichoid lesions also seen in

 

  • FISH TANK/SWIMMING POOL GRANULOMA
  • LUPUS VULGARIS.

 

The given images show the distribution of lesions along lymphatics.

 

 

Histopathology:  Asteroid bodies are seen.


Treatment: Itraconazole / Terbinafine / Saturated solution of Potassium Iodide.

 

Option D. Phaeohyphomycosis:

  • Represents a group of infections caused by various dematiaceous fungi.
  • Lesions can vary in appearance from nodules to cysts or abscesses.
  • Unlike chromoblastomycosis, phaeohyphomycosis does not characteristically have sclerotic or "copper penny" bodies under the microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chromoblastomycosis is identified by its clinical presentation of verrucous skin lesions and the histopathological finding of sclerotic or copper penny bodies, indicative of infection with dematiaceous fungi.

questions.text: A child was born with membranes around the body and had ectropion and eclabium. He is brought to the OPD with lesions covering his face, trunk, and extremities. Which of the following is an unlikely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ichthyosis vulgaris

 

  • The clinical image depicts a newborn covered in a shiny membrane that resembles parchment, suggesting a disorder on the autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis spectrum (Lamellar ichthyosis, Bathing suit ichthyosis, Harlequin ichthyosis)
  • Icthyosis vulgaris is an autosomal dominant condition caused by mutation in the Filaggrin gene (FLG).
  • Ichthyosis vulgaris is unlikely because it does not manifest at birth.

 

Fig: Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis, Shedding of collodion membranes after 1 week.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lamellar ichthyosis

  • Description: Infants with lamellar ichthyosis are often born with a collodion membrane, which sheds after a few weeks. The skin then becomes darkly pigmented with large, plate-like scales. Ectropion and eclabium can also be present.

 

Option C. Bathing suit ichthyosis

  • Description: This is a rare type of ichthyosis where the scaling is restricted to the trunk, sparing the extremities and face. It's called "bathing suit" due to the distribution pattern resembling the area covered by a bathing suit.

 

Option D. Harlequin ichthyosis

  • Description: This is a severe form of ichthyosis, where infants are born with very thick skin that forms large, diamond-shaped plates separated by deep fissures as seen in the below image.

 

 

  • Features like ectropion, eclabium, and respiratory difficulties are common.

 

Autosomal Recessive Congenital Ichthyosis (ARCI) includes the following:

 

  • Lamellar ichthyosis (LI)
  • Bathing suit ichthyosis (BSI)
  • Harlequin ichthyosis (HI)
  • Congenital Ichthyosiform erythroderma (CIE)
  • Self-limiting congenital ichthyisis (SLCI)
  • Collodion baby

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ichthyosis vulgaris is an unlikely diagnosis in a new-born presenting with a collodion membrane, ectropion, eclabium, and extensive skin lesions, given that ichthyosis vulgaris is typically a milder form and less likely to present with such severe symptoms at birth.

 

References

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 65 Page no 65.4, 65.6-65.10

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8161842/

questions.text: In the case of a child presenting to the OPD with tense bullae over the torso, and a biopsy of the lesion revealing subepidermal blistering and neutrophil infiltration, what is the preferred drug for treatment? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dapsone

 

  • A diagnosis of linear lgA disease (LIGA), or childhood chronic bullous disease is suggested by the clinical picture of tense blisters with subepidermal separation and neutrophilic infiltration at the basement membrane in a child.
  • This is an autoimmune blistering disorder that can clinically and histologically resemble bullous pemphigoid but is distinguished by linear deposits of IgA at the basement membrane zone.

 

Dapsone:

 

  • The preferred medication to treat LIGA is dapsone.
  • It typically leads to rapid clinical improvement in CBDC
  • Dapsone, which primarily kills bacteria, also has an anti-inflammatory effect by reducing neutrophil enzyme activity.
  • As a result, it is effective in the management of LIGA.
  • Other options such as rituximab, cyclosporine, and azathioprine are reserved for cases that do not respond to dapsone or when dapsone is contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rituximab: This is a monoclonal antibody that targets CD20 on B-cells and is used in a variety of autoimmune diseases, including those with blistering skin manifestations like pemphigus vulgaris. It is not the first-line therapy for Linear IgA disease.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine: This is an immunosuppressant that inhibits T-cell activation and is used in severe cases of many autoimmune disorders and in transplant patients. It may be used in refractory cases of Linear IgA disease but is not the first choice due to potential side effects, especially in children.

 

Option D. Azathioprine: This immunosuppressive agent is used as a steroid-sparing drug in various autoimmune conditions. It is not the first-line treatment for Linear IgA disease and is considered in cases that are refractory to dapsone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for Linear IgA disease (Chronic Bullous Disease of Childhood) is dapsone, due to its efficacy in managing conditions with neutrophilic infiltrates.

 

Ref - Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page no 989,998

questions.text: Desmosomes are abundant in which of the following layer of skin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A

 

Desmosomes are abundant in the stratum spinosum layer of the epidermis of the skin. Stratum spinosum in the above image is represented by 'A'.

 

The desmosomes appear like spines on microscopy and hence this layer is also called as the prickle layer.

 

Keratinocytes in the skin's epidermis are connected by desmosomes, also known as macula adherens. It is a cell structure designed specifically for adhesion between cells.

 

  • Due to their strong adhesiveness, they can withstand mechanical stress.
  • Desmoglein (Dsg), Desmocollin (DsC), and DesmoPlakin (Dp) are some of the proteins found in desmosomes.
  • Acantholysis can result from the separation of keratinocytes caused by the loss of any one protein.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune condition brought on by antibodies that target Desmoglein found in desmosomes.
  • Loss of desmosomes causes keratinocyte cohesion to break down (acantholysis), which leads to blister formation.
  • Diseases of the skin and the heart can result from desmosome dysfunction. The primary cause of arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy is mutations within the desmosomes (ARVC).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stratum Corneum (B): This layer is the outermost layer of the epidermis, consisting of dead, keratinized cells. Its main function is to provide a barrier to protect underlying tissue.

 

Option C. Stratum Basale (D): This is the deepest layer of the epidermis, responsible for generating new cells. Desmosomes are present here but not as abundant as in the stratum spinosum.

 

Option D. Stratum Granulosum (C): This layer is characterized by granules of keratohyalin, which play a role in the keratinization process of the skin cells. While desmosomes may be found in this layer, they are more prominent in the stratum spinosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stratum spinosum, indicated by arrow A, is the layer of the skin where desmosomes are most abundant. These structures are key for cell adhesion and strength in this layer, which is situated above the stratum basale and below the stratum granulosum.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page no 2.1, 2.2, 2.18

choices.text: Half of the cases resolve spontaneously after bacilli exposure
Spontaneous remission is more common in children than in adults
Indeterminate leprosy has more remission than tuberculoid leprosy

questions.text: Which among the following is correct regarding the healing of leprosy if left untreated? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Indeterminate leprosy has more remission than tuberculoid leprosy.

 

Among the given options, Indeterminate leprosy has more remission than tuberculoid is the most appropriate answer

 

The bacillus Mycobacterium leprae is the source of the chronic infectious granulomatous disease known as leprosy (Hansen's disease).

 

Clinically, leprosy can exhibit one or more of the following symptoms

 

  • Patches of hypopigmentation
  • Presence of thickened nerves, and
  • Partial or complete loss of cutaneous sensation in the affected areas (First sensory modality to be lost is Temperature (hot/cold differentiation).
  • The presence of acid-fast bacilli in nasal smears or the skin.

 

Leprosy symptoms vary depending on how an individual's immune system reacts to the bacillus Mycobacterium leprae. Spontaneous resolution can be seen in about 80–90% (NOT just 50% as given in Option B) of people after being exposed to bacteria.  The remaining patients get clinical leprosy. Indeterminate leprosy typically has hypopigmented, ill-defined lesions. 75 percent of those Indeterminate leprosy patients experience spontaneous remission.

 

Clinically, very few patients exhibit either lepromatous leprosy or tuberculoid leprosy. As a result, compared to patients with tuberculoid leprosy, more patients with indeterminate leprosy experience spontaneous remission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No spontaneous remission is seen: Incorrect. Spontaneous remission can occur in leprosy, particularly in the indeterminate and sometimes in the tuberculoid forms due to the individual's immune response.

 

Note - Even in the absence of specific treatment, a majority (80-90%) of patients tend to get cured spontaneously.

 

Option B. Half of the cases resolve spontaneously after bacilli exposure. Incorrect. While many individuals may be exposed to Mycobacterium leprae and not develop full-blown leprosy due to a robust immune response, the assertion that half of the cases resolve spontaneously is not accurate. A higher percentage may never progress to clinical disease.

 

Option C. Spontaneous remission in children is variable when compared to adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Spontaneous remission occurs even in the absence of specific treatment in majority (almost 80-90%) of the patients, but when compared to adults, in children spontaneous cure is very much variable.
  • If left untreated, Indeterminate leprosy has a higher rate of spontaneous remission compared to tuberculoid leprosy.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 28.7

Parks textbook of preventive & social medicine 26th edition Pg 359

questions.text: A young male came with GI complaints like malabsorption, diarrhea. Cutaneous examination noted itchy lesions on the skin with blistering. On histopathology, cryptitis and flattened villi were noted. His condition improved with a gluten-free diet. What is the specific antibody in this condition? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tissue Transglutaminase 3 (ttg-3)

 

The patient's symptoms, including gastrointestinal complaints like malabsorption and diarrhea, combined with itchy skin lesions and histopathological findings of cryptitis and flattened villi, are indicative of dermatitis herpetiformis. This condition is closely associated with celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten ingestion.

 

The specific antibody associated with dermatitis herpetiformis is tissue transglutaminase 3 (ttg-3). This antibody is primarily responsible for the characteristic skin lesions seen in dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Anti-nuclear antibodies: Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs) are a group of autoantibodies that target components of the cell nucleus. They are commonly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and other autoimmune conditions but are not related to celiac disease or dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of tissue transglutaminase 3 (ttg-3) antibodies is a hallmark of dermatitis herpetiformis, a condition associated with celiac disease. This autoimmune response is triggered by gluten ingestion and manifests with both gastrointestinal and cutaneous symptoms.

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple painful blisters on the trunk as shown in the image. Identify the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Herpes zoster

 

The above image shows multiple painful blisters on the trunk along dermatome which is suggestive of herpes zoster or shingles.

 

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV)

 

  • It is a human herpes virus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution.
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

• Painful zoster infections in adults

• Facial zoster at any age

• Immunocompromised

 

Complication of zoster:

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chicken pox (Varicella)

 

  • Features: Caused by the primary infection with varicella-zoster virus. It generally presents as an itchy, diffuse vesicular rash that starts on the face and trunk before spreading to the extremities. The rash evolves through stages, with papules, vesicles, pustules, and crusts present simultaneously.
  • Why it doesn't match: While chickenpox can produce blisters on the trunk, they are typically itchy rather than painful and appear in multiple stages of healing rather than uniformly as blisters. Also, chickenpox tends to start on the face and spread, not solely localized to the trunk.

 

Option C. Measles

 

  • Features: Caused by the measles virus, it presents with a high fever, malaise, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis followed by a characteristic maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads downward. Koplik spots (white spots) on the buccal mucosa are a pathognomonic sign.
  • Why it doesn't match: Measles produces a maculopapular rash, not blisters. The systemic symptoms and the pattern of rash spread also don't align with the description.

 

Option D. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID)

 

  • Features: It's a primary immunodeficiency disorder where there is a defect in both T and B cell immune responses. Infants with SCID present with recurrent infections, failure to thrive, and chronic diarrhoea. They are vulnerable to opportunistic infections.
  • Why it doesn't match: SCID itself does not cause blisters. Patients with SCID are susceptible to numerous infections due to their compromised immune system, but the mere presence of blisters would not immediately point to SCID without other accompanying symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes zoster is identified as painful, unilateral vesicular lesions within a dermatomal distribution on the patient's trunk.

 

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Page nos 4.13, 25.27-25.28

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition Page no 106

questions.text: A young female presented with vaginal itching and green frothy genital discharge. Strawberry vagina is seen on examination. What will be the drug of choice?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Metronidazole

 

This is the description of vaginal discharge caused by Trichomonas vaginalis.

 

Salient features:

 

  • It is transmitted by sexual intercourse, with an incubation period of 4-21 days.
  • It typically results in vaginal soreness, frequent urination, and a copious, frothy, yellow-green discharge in females with a pH > 4.5.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  1. Direct Immunofluorescent antibody staining – Most sensitive
  2. Wet mount – Motile flagella seen
  3. Culture - Feinberg-Whittington media

 

Treatment:

 

  • D.O.C. – Metronidazole (2 gm Oral)
  • An alternate dose is metronidazole 500 mg orally twice a day for 7 days.
  • Prophylaxis to all sexual partners.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Azithromycin

  • Primary uses: It is an antibiotic used primarily to treat bacterial infections like chlamydia, respiratory tract infections, and certain types of skin infections. It's a drug of choice for chlamydia and can also be used in the treatment of gonorrhea (often in combination with ceftriaxone).

 

Option C. Doxycycline

  • Primary uses: It's an antibiotic that is frequently used to treat bacterial infections such as chlamydia, non-gonococcal urethritis, and pelvic inflammatory disease. It's also a drug of choice for Lyme disease and is used for the prophylaxis of malaria in certain regions.

 

Option D. Oral fluconazole

  • Primary uses: It's an antifungal drug that's used primarily to treat and prevent fungal infections, especially Candida infections. It's the drug of choice for vaginal candidiasis (yeast infection). It's also used for systemic candida infections, cryptococcal meningitis, and prophylaxis in immunocompromised patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metronidazole is the treatment of choice for Trichomoniasis, which presents with vaginal itching, green frothy discharge, and a "strawberry vagina" on examination, distinguishing it from bacterial and fungal causes of vaginal symptoms that would require different treatments.

 

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Chapter 33, Page nos 33.35 and 33.36

Question Level – Intermediate 

Question Id-7463 Unique Key-Q3304541

questions.text: A young woman presents with complaints of a painless ulcer in the genital area. It is associated with non-tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Syphilis

 

Given scenario points out to a diagnosis of syphilis

 

ACQUIRED SYPHILIS:

 

Mode of acquisition - Sexual transmission & Blood transfusion

 

Stages are as follows –

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chancroid: In this condition both genital ulcer and inguinal lymphadenopathy are painful. It is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi, with an incubation period of 2-5 days.

 

 

Option C. Herpes genitalis: It causes painful ulcers in the genital region and localized tender lymphadenopathy, caused by HSV 2 > 1.

 

 

Option D. Granuloma inguinale (aka donovanosis): It is caused by the bacterium Calymmatobacter / Klebsiella granulomatis. There is NO pain in Ulcer & NO Lymphadenopathy

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary syphilis (syphiLESS) is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a Painless genital ulcer and Painless inguinal lymphadenopathy, which are classic presentations of this sexually transmitted infection.

 

References: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page no: 28.8-29, 29.13-16

Jawetz Melnick & Adelbergs Medical Microbiology 28th edition Page no 339, 341, 342

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 379-383

questions.text: What is the skin manifestation seen resulting from drugs used to treat amebic dysentery? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fixed drug eruption

 

  • Among the various medication available, metronidazole is drug used to treat amebic dysentery most frequently & it is associated with fixed drug eruption (FDE), which is a drug-induced skin manifestation.
  • Metronidazole can cause maculopapular rashes, but it also has a higher likelihood of causing a fixed drug eruption.
  • Fixed drug eruptions/ reactions are characterized by sharply demarcated, dull red to brown lesions. They can cause a burning sensation and appear on the lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa.
  • They frequently appear alone or in small groups and return to the same spot. On re-exposure to the harmful drug, however, new lesions may develop on various body parts. FDE is a form of delayed hypersensitivity reaction. Some of the most frequently prescribed medications that cause FDE are NSAIDs Tetracyclines and paracetamol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urticaria

 

  • While urticaria (hives) can be a common reaction to many drugs, it is not specifically associated with the treatment of amoebic dysentery.
  • Urticaria is characterized by raised, often itchy, red or skin-colored wheals on the surface of the skin as shown below.

 

 

  • It is usually as an immediate hypersensitivity reaction.

 

Option C. Maculopapular rash

 

  • A maculopapular rash is a skin change that can occur with many conditions or as a reaction to various drugs.
  • It is characterized by a flat, red area on the skin that is covered with small confluent bumps as shown in the below image.

 

 

  • While this type of rash can be seen with many types of medications, it is not the most characteristic skin manifestation resulting from drugs used to treat amoebic dysentery.

 

Option D. Atopic dermatitis

 

  • Atopic dermatitis is a chronic skin condition characterized by itchy, inflamed skin.
  • It is not a drug-induced condition but rather a type of eczema that has a strong genetic predisposition and is commonly associated with allergic diseases.
  • It is not typically associated with amoebic dysentery treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fixed drug eruption is a skin manifestation commonly associated with the drugs used to treat amoebic dysentery (Metronidazole).
  • While other skin reactions can occur due to various drugs, fixed drug eruptions are characterized by recurrent lesions at the same site upon re-exposure to a particular drug.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 118 page no 118.11-12

questions.text: What type of tinea is likely affecting the 10-year-old child who presents with patchy hair loss as shown in the image below, along with the presence of black dots in the areas of hair loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endothrix

 

The given clinical picture is suggestive of endothrix type of tinea capitis.

 

Tinea capitis is a dermatophyte infection primarily occurring in children.

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

  • Ectothrix - Spores & fungus present outside the hair shaft.
  • Endothrix - Spores & fungi present inside the hair shaft.

 

 

 

Kerion:

 

  • Presents in Children with boggy swelling, easily pluckable hair, with regional lymphadenopathy.
  • It is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis.
  • The most common causative organisms of kerion are Zoophilic dermatophytes, T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes. In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation.

 

 

  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount
  • Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum is Griseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton associated Tinea capitis - Terbinafine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of patchy hair loss with black dots in the areas of hair loss in a child is indicative of an endothrix type of tinea capitis, where the fungal spores are located inside the hair shaft, causing it to break at the scalp level.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.8, 32.38-32.40

questions.text: Which of the following is the least likely condition to exhibit lesions and changes on the anterior shin? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypothyroidism

 

Hypothyroidism is the least likely among the given conditions to present with specific skin lesions or changes on the anterior shin. Hypothyroidism can lead to generalized skin changes like dryness and edema (notably myxedema), but it is not typically associated with localized lesions on the shin.

 

Myxedema (severe hypothyroidism) is unlikely to present with lesions over shin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sarcoidosis: In Lofgren syndrome which is acute form of sarcoidosis, Erythema nodosum Skin lesions can be seen on shin as seen in the image below.

 

 

Option B. Diabetes: Necrobiosis lipoidica Diabeticorum classically seen on anterior surface of legs.

 

 

Necrobiosis lipoidica Diabeticorum

 

Option C. Hyperthyroidism: Pretibial myxoedema is the infiltrative dermopathy (mucin deposition) seen over shin and it can be seen in Grave's disease which is a type of hyperthyroidism.

 

Pretibial myxoedema is depicted in below image:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Page no 59.11, 64.5, 98.6, 149.10

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a patient who has paronychia on their index finger and is also showing a reddish streak on their forearm, as depicted in the image? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amoxiclav

 

  • The above image depicts paronychia associated with a reddish erythematous streak-like lesion on the hand suggestive of paronychia associated with lymphangitis, which is managed by elevating the affected extremity and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • A broad-spectrum antibiotic like Amoxiclav is appropriate for covering both the pathogens commonly responsible for the initial localized infection and the secondary systemic spread.

 

Acute paronychia:

 

It is infection of the nail fold which is characterized by inflammation, swelling and abscess formation.

Most common causative organism - Staphylococcus aureus
 

Diagnosis - Clinical

 

Management - Systemic antibiotics may be needed for deep infections.

 

Treatment of Acute paronychia -

 

  • Abscesses - Incised and drained (Abscess is often opened by pushing the nail fold away from the nail plate).
     
  • Antibiotics - Semisynthetic penicillin/cephalosporin with excellent anti-staphylococcal orally.

 

Complications - Osteitis and amputation.

 

Lymphangitis: represents acute inflammation elicited by the spread of bacterial infections into lymphatics with group A beta haemolytic streptococci being the most common causative agent.

 

Clinical features: Lymphangitis manifests as red painful subcutaneous streaks & painful enlargement of the draining lymph nodes (lymphadenitis). It is managed by elevating the affected extremity & broad spectrum antibiotics.

 

Chronic paronychia:

 

  • Most common causative organism - Candida albicans.
  • Candidal paronychia is most common in individuals who have their hands in water for a great deal of time.
  • Given recent evidence that Candida colonization may play a secondary role in chronic paronychia, with the primary insult being skin barrier breakdown resulting from wet work and possible contact dermatitis, a role for topical corticosteroids has been demonstrated.
  • Treatment - Topical antifungals & Topical corticosteroids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metronidazole: Primarily effective against anaerobic bacteria and certain protozoa. While useful in skin and soft tissue infections involving anaerobes, it is not the first-line treatment for paronychia or lymphangitis which typically involve aerobic gram-positive cocci.

 

Option C. Amikacin: A powerful aminoglycoside antibiotic used primarily for severe, hospital-acquired infections with multi-drug resistant bacteria. It is not typically used for initial treatment of common skin infections due to its potential for causing significant side effects, including nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity.

 

Option D. Norfloxacin: A fluoroquinolone antibiotic used primarily for gastrointestinal and urinary tract infections. While it has broad-spectrum activity, it is generally not the first choice for skin infections and is less effective against gram-positive organisms commonly causing skin infections.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Combination antibiotic Amoxiclav is indicated for the treatment of paronychia complicated by lymphangitis due to its broad-spectrum activity against both Gram-positive and resistant bacteria.

questions.text: Identify the structures as marked in the image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Errector pili muscle

 

In the image, the marked structure corresponds to the Errector pili muscle (C).

Errector Pili Muscle is a tiny muscle attached to the base of a hair follicle. When this muscle contracts, it causes the hair to stand upright, a phenomenon known as "goosebumps."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sebaceous glands: Incorrect because the sebaceous glands are associated with hair follicles, but the marked structure is clearly a muscle, not a gland. Sebaceous Glands are small oil-producing glands present in the skin of mammals. They are usually associated with hair follicles and release sebum, which helps to lubricate the skin and hair.

 

Option B. Eccrine glands: Incorrect because these glands open directly onto the skin surface without any connection to the hair follicle, whereas the marked structure is connected to a hair follicle. Eccrine Glands are sweat glands that are not associated with hair follicles and play a key role in thermoregulation by secreting sweat.

 

Option D. Apocrine glands: Incorrect because apocrine glands are larger and typically located deeper in the dermis. These are sweat glands usually associated with hair follicles in areas such as the armpits and groin. They secrete a thicker, milky sweat that, when broken down by bacteria, can produce body odor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Errector pili muscle is a small muscle attached to hair follicles responsible for causing hairs to stand on end when contracted, leading to "goosebumps."

questions.text: A child came with malnutrition and follicular hyperkeratotic skin lesions. There was a deficiency of Vitamin A and Essential Fatty Acids. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phrynoderma

 

Phrynoderma, also known as "toad skin," is a type of dermatosis characterized by hyperkeratotic papules that primarily occur over the extensor surfaces such as the elbows and knees. This condition is closely associated with nutritional deficiencies, particularly of Vitamin A and essential fatty acids. In severe cases, deficiencies in other vitamins like Vitamin B complex, Vitamin C, and Vitamin E have also been observed to contribute to this condition.

 

The presentation of follicular hyperkeratotic lesions in a malnourished child, along with documented deficiencies of Vitamin A and essential fatty acids, strongly points to phrynoderma. Recognizing this characteristic presentation is crucial in diagnosing and treating the condition effectively.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scurvy: Scurvy is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin C and is characterized by symptoms such as bleeding gums, bruising, and petechiae, but it does not typically cause follicular hyperkeratotic lesions. Therefore, this is not the correct diagnosis.

 

Option C. Keratosis pilaris: This is a common, benign condition that presents with rough, small, acne-like bumps, typically on the arms, thighs, cheeks, and buttocks. It is not associated with the nutritional deficiencies described in the question, making it an unlikely diagnosis here.

 

Option D. Keratosis follicularis (Darier's disease): This is a genetic skin disorder characterized by greasy, warty papules and plaques in seborrheic areas like the scalp, forehead, upper arms, chest, and back. It is not associated with vitamin deficiencies or malnutrition, which makes it an in Ans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phrynoderma is associated with malnutrition and deficiencies in Vitamin A and essential fatty acids, and it presents with follicular hyperkeratotic skin lesions, particularly over the elbows and knees.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 13-year-old boy with a history of chronic and recurrent itchy flexural lesions, considering his family history of asthma?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atopic dermatitis

 

The image displays scratch marks and excoriations caused by pruritic lesions at a flexural site. The patient has a personal history of chronic and recurrent course, and there is also a family history of atopy, specifically asthma. These findings suggest a diagnosis of atopic dermatitis (AD) or atopic eczema (AE).

 

Atopic dermatitis (AD):

 

  • It is a chronic inflammatory condition that tends to persist or exhibit chronic relapses.
  • In infants, the first site of involvement is often the face.
  • Flexural distribution is observed in both the childhood and adult phases of the condition, while in the infantile phase, extensor distribution is more typical.

 

Atopic eczema can be divided into 3 phases:

 

  1. Infantile
  2. Childhood
  3. Adult

 

 

Atopic eczema infantile variant with face affected:

 

 

  • Atopic dermatitis typically presents with erythematous papules or papulovesicular lesions, often appearing in early childhood.
  • As the condition progresses, the lesions may evolve into excoriated and lichenified areas. Atopic dermatitis is commonly associated with secondary infections and skin dryness.
  • In the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis, the UK refinement of the Hanifin & Rajka criteria is employed.

 

UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (Eczema).

 

  • An itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child)
  • Plus, three or more of the following
    1. Onset below age 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
    2. History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
    3. History of a generally dry skin
    4. Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first degree relative in children under 4 years)
    5. Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/ forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

 

Clinical features of AD include:

 

  • Dennie-morgan fold under lower eyelid
  • Allergic shiners – periorbital pigmentation
  • Allergic salute – horizontal groove on dorsum of nasal bridge

 

Fig: Dennie-morgan fold

 

Complications of AD:

  • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism to cause secondary infections in the lesions of atopic dermatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seborrheic dermatitis:

 

  • This is a chronic condition that primarily affects sebum-rich areas of the body such as the scalp, face, and central chest.
  • It's characterized by yellowish, greasy scales and underlying erythema as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • While it can be itchy, its distribution and features are different from the description given.
  • There is no direct association between seborrheic dermatitis and a family history of asthma.

 

Option C. Allergic contact dermatitis:

 

  • This results from direct skin contact with allergens. It's an immunological response to a substance the individual has become sensitized to.
  • The lesions would be more correlated with contact to specific allergens, and it's not typically chronic or recurrent unless there is repeated exposure to the same allergen.
  • The distribution would be more in line with areas that contacted the allergen, rather than the typical flexural pattern described.

 

Option D. Erysipelas:

 

  • Erysipelas is an acute bacterial skin infection, typically caused by Group A Streptococcus.
  • It presents as a well-demarcated, raised, erythematous, and tender skin lesion, often accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever.
  • This condition is acute, not chronic or recurrent as described in the scenario.
  • There's no association with a family history of asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify atopic dermatitis as a chronic, pruritic inflammatory skin disease commonly associated with flexural distribution of eczematous lesions and a family history of atopic conditions, such as asthma.

 

 

Reference:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 2 Chapter 41 page no 41.1, 41.2, 41.13-19

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 3 Chapter 149 page no 149.21

Online resources:

https://www.jaad.org/article/S0190-9622(13)01095-5/fulltext

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman with a history of chronic sun exposure presented with bilateral brownish pigmentation over the face as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Melasma

 

Melasma is characterized by bilateral, symmetrical brownish pigmentation, primarily on the face, commonly seen in pregnant women or individuals with chronic sun exposure. In this case, the patient's history of pregnancy and chronic sun exposure, along with the image showing patchy pigmentation, strongly suggests melasma. Melasma in pregnant women is often referred to as chloasma or the "mask of pregnancy." It is associated with hormonal changes and UV exposure. Additionally, melasma is often linked to thyroid disorders.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanoma: Melanoma is typically characterized by the ABCDE features: Asymmetry, Border irregularity, Color variation, Diameter greater than 6mm, and Evolution of the lesion.

 

 

Option C. Suntan: A suntan results in diffuse pigmentation over sun-exposed areas, usually with an initial red phase. The pigmentation in a suntan is not patchy as seen in the image provided but rather more uniform. Therefore, suntan is not the correct diagnosis.

 

 

Option D. Nevus of OTA: This condition presents with unilateral blue or grey pigmentation, often involving the sclera and skin on the face. The absence of these characteristic features and the presence of bilateral brown pigmentation make Nevus of OTA an incorrect choice.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melasma, especially in pregnant women, presents as bilateral, symmetrical brownish patches on the face, often linked to sun exposure and hormonal changes.

questions.text: The presence of a pearly white papule on the mother's forehead, which is also seen in her infant, can be due to which of the following virus? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pox virus

 

The above image shows shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules which are suggestive of molluscum contagiosum. It’s a DNA virus.

 

  • It is mainly caused by Pox virus which is a DNA virus.
  • Virus: Molluscum Contagiosum Virus (MCV).
    • MCV-1: Children over Face (Not seen over palms & soles).
    • MCV-2: Adults producing lesions over Genitals.
  • Microscopic examination - Lesions shows eosinophilic inclusions called Henderson-Patterson bodies.
  • Transmission: Skin to skin contact.

 

Note: Sexually transmitted molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Usually, it is self-limiting and will disappear by itself. Thus, there is no need for treatment.
  • Destruction with cantharidin, trichloroacetic acid, diluted liquefied phenol, or surgical removal are a few options.

 

Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon: New lesions develop along the line of trauma due to Autoinoculation.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. HPV (Human Papilloma Virus) leads to warts, but the lesions are typically rough-surfaced as shown in the image below, rather than pearly.

 

 

  • Option C. Adenovirus does not typically cause visible skin manifestations like the one shown.
  • Option D. Herpes virus causes vesicular and ulcerative lesions as shown in the image below, rather than pearly papules.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of pearly white papules in both a mother and her infant is indicative of molluscum contagiosum, a skin infection caused by a Poxvirus.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 25, Page no 25.12-14

questions.text: Based on the image, a 60-year-old male patient with diabetes presents with progressive skin lesions. What could be the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma

 

The image above displays a central rodent ulcer, which indicates basal cell carcinoma. This malignant tumor exhibits characteristics of slow local invasion and mainly affects the pilosebaceous skin.

 

Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC):

 

  • The most significant predisposing factor for basal cell carcinoma is exposure to ultraviolet radiation. Other risk factors include ionizing radiation, coal tar, aromatic hydrocarbons, and arsenic exposure.
  • Basal cell carcinoma predominantly affects middle-aged or elderly men with a history of excessive sun exposure, often among individuals with white skin, aged between 40 to 80 years.

 

Morphologically, basal cell carcinoma can be of 2 types:

 

1. Localized types: These are more common and include:

 

  • Nodular and nodulocystic BCC: Representing the majority of cases, these appear as pearly, waxy nodules with rolled borders and sometimes central ulceration or depression, known as umbilication.

 

 

  • Pigmented BCC: These are similar to nodular BCC but contain melanin, giving them a darker appearance.
  • Nevoid BCC: This type is rarer and can resemble benign moles.

 

2. Generalized types: These are less common and can be more challenging to treat due to their growth patterns:

 

  • Superficial multifocal and spreading BCC: Often appearing as scaly, erythematous patches that can be mistaken for eczema or psoriasis.
  • Infiltrative BCC: These grow more aggressively and can invade deeper tissues.
  • Cicatrizing (or sclerosing) BCC: This type can cause scarring as it grows.

 

While nodular BCC is the most common form, it is important for medical practitioners to recognize the less common types due to their growth patterns and potential for tissue destruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)

 

  • It typically presents as a firm, red nodule or a flat sore with a scaly crust as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • While it's possible for diabetic patients to develop SCC, the description provided fits BCC more closely.

 

Option C. Melasma

 

  • It is characterized by brown to gray-brown patches as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • It is usually seen on the face.
  • It is more common in women, especially during pregnancy, and is not typically associated with progressive lesions.

 

Option D. Discoid lupus erythematosus

 

  • It often presents as a chronic rash with red, inflamed, and scaly patches that can cause scarring, usually on the face, ears, and scalp, as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • It is an autoimmune condition and not directly linked to diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an elderly patient, progressive pearly or waxy skin lesions, especially if located on sun-exposed areas, are likely indicative of basal cell carcinoma.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page no 4.15, 51.3, 88.10-12, 141.1-16

Robbins basic pathology 10th edition page no 1148

Bailey & Loves short practice of surgery 27th edition Page no 599, 604-6011

questions.text: Coral red fluorescence on Wood's lamp seen in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Erythrasma

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is erythrasma.

 

Erythrasma is caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum and typically presents as hyperpigmented patches in skin folds, such as the axilla and toe web spaces. When examined under a Wood's lamp, which emits ultraviolet light at a wavelength of 365 nanometers, erythrasma exhibits a characteristic coral red fluorescence due to the porphyrins produced by the bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitiligo: Under a Wood's lamp, vitiligo shows a milky white fluorescence. This is due to the absence of melanin in the depigmented areas of the skin.

 

Option C. Pityriasis versicolor: Caused by the yeast Malassezia furfur, this condition shows a yellow fluorescence under a Wood's lamp.

 

Option D. Acanthosis nigricans: This condition does not exhibit any fluorescence under a Wood's lamp. It presents with hyperpigmentation and a velvety texture, particularly in skin folds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythrasma, caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum, presents with coral red fluorescence under a Wood's lamp, distinguishing it from other dermatological conditions that may exhibit different types of fluorescence or none at all.

questions.text: Drug resistance is most seen with which STI? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gonorrhoea

 

Explanation:

 

  • Gonorrhoea, caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae, is known for developing significant resistance to multiple antibiotics.
  • Over the years, Neisseria gonorrhoeae has shown resistance to several classes of antibiotics, including penicillin, tetracycline, and fluoroquinolones.
  • More recently, there has been an increasing number of reports of resistance to cephalosporins, including ceftriaxone, which is currently the first-line treatment for Gonorrhoea.
  • The development of drug resistance in Gonorrhoea is largely due to the bacterium's ability to acquire resistance genes through horizontal gene transfer and spontaneous mutations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, has not shown the same level of widespread antibiotic resistance as gonorrhoea. It is typically treated with antibiotics such as azithromycin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, or erythromycin.

 

Option B. Donovanosis: Donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, is relatively rare and has not shown significant issues with antibiotic resistance. It is usually treated with azithromycin, doxycycline, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, is typically treated with penicillin. Although there have been some cases of resistance to macrolides like azithromycin, penicillin remains highly effective, and there is no widespread resistance to it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gonorrhoea is the STI most commonly associated with significant and increasing antibiotic resistance, posing a major challenge to treatment and control efforts worldwide.

questions.text: Identify the following lines: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blaschko lines

 

Blaschko lines, also known as Blaschko's lines, are an intricate and unique pattern of skin markings that follow a specific distribution on the human body. They are not visible under normal circumstances and only become apparent when certain skin conditions or genetic disorders manifest. They are thought to represent the migration and proliferation of embryonic cells during early development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hinderer’s lines - Two intersecting lines, one from the ala to the tragus and one from the lateral canthus.

 

 

Option B. Marionette lines are wrinkles at the corners of mouth

 

 

Option C. Relaxed skin tension lines refer to furrows that are created when the skin is pinched and relaxed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blaschko lines offer a fascinating insight into human embryonic development and their pattern can help diagnose several dermatological conditions. Each of these lines has specific implications in medical practice, particularly in dermatology, plastic surgery, and cosmetic procedures, illustrating the intersection of clinical knowledge with aesthetic considerations.

questions.text: A school going child had applied henna and comes to dermatology OPD with the following lesions What is the possible diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dermatitis artefacta

 

The given image points towards a likely diagnosis of dermatitis Artefacta.

 

  • Dermatitis artefacta is a psychodermatological disorder where lesions are self-inflicted, often due to psychological stress or disorders. The pattern of the lesions, which are well-circumscribed and may follow an accessible pattern that the child could reach, is suggestive of dermatitis artefacta.
  • Dermatitis artefacta is a condition in which the patient deliberately produces skin lesions without any rational motive. This is a psychological ailment where the patient is fully aware of their actions.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Indicated by the symmetrical placement of lesions in accessible areas on the face, neck, chest etc. Additionally, the lesions may exhibit varying stages of healing, similar to an abrasion.
  • These visible symptoms of dermatitis artefacta can be seen as a form of nonverbal communication, representing a "cry for attention and help" from a patient who is unable to express their needs through meaningful verbal communication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contact dermatitis due to henna:

 

  • Contact dermatitis from henna, often related to the chemical para-phenylenediamine (PPD), usually manifests as a diffuse, erythematous rash in areas where the henna was applied.
  • If the reaction were due to henna, one would expect to see an affected scalp where the henna was applied.
  • However, the presence of localized lesions on the cheek and the normal appearance of the scalp suggests that this is not a case of allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) caused by henna.

 

Option C. Polymorphic light eruption (PLE):

 

  • This is an abnormal reaction to sunlight it is not expected to have a direct correlation with the application of henna.
  • Lesions will be small, itchy papules or Papulo-vesicles on an erythematous background. They will also be monomorphic (unlike as the name suggests).

 

Option D. Vitiligo:

 

  • Vitiligo is characterized by depigmentation of the skin and would not present with erythematous or inflamed lesions as shown in the image.
  • It represents a loss of pigment and is not physically raised or inflamed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In assessing skin lesions, it's important to consider the psychological aspect of dermatology.
  • Dermatitis artefacta should be suspected in lesions that are localized, well-circumscribed, and do not have a distribution pattern consistent with the history or other physical causes.

 

Ref:

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology 9th edition 128.13

Kaplan & Saddocks concise textbook of clinical Psychiatry 11th edition page 435, 436

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition 405

questions.text: Which nutritional deficiency is commonly associated with a chronic alcoholic presenting with a pruritic eczematous rash on the neck and dorsum of hands? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

Explanation:

 

Chronic alcoholism often leads to poor dietary intake, resulting in various nutritional deficiencies.

 

One of the most significant deficiencies in chronic alcoholics is niacin (vitamin B3). Niacin deficiency leads to a condition called pellagra, which is characterized by the "3 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia.

 

The dermatitis in pellagra is specifically photodermatitis, meaning it occurs in areas exposed to sunlight, such as the neck and dorsum of the hands. The rash is pruritic and eczematous, commonly presenting as Casal's necklace around the neck and gauntlet sign on the hands.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Riboflavin: Deficiency in riboflavin (vitamin B2) typically leads to symptoms such as cheilosis, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis but does not cause the characteristic dermatitis seen in niacin deficiency.

 

Option C. Folic acid: Folic acid deficiency often presents with megaloblastic anemia and glossitis, not with the dermatological symptoms described in the question.

 

Option D. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency leads to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, primarily affecting the cardiovascular and nervous systems, rather than causing the dermatological symptoms seen with niacin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency, commonly seen in chronic alcoholics, leads to pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. The dermatitis is photodermatitis, presenting with a pruritic eczematous rash on sun-exposed areas like the neck and dorsum of the hands. ​

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with painful genital ulcers along with painful inguinal buboes. He had a history of multiple sexual partners. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chancroid

 

The patient's symptoms of painful genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes) are characteristic of Chancroid. Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and typically presents with painful ulcers on the genitals and tender, often pus-filled lymph nodes (buboes) in the groin.

 

When differentiating between sexually transmitted infections that cause genital ulcers, it is important to note whether the ulcers are painful or painless:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LGV (Lymphogranuloma Venereum): Incorrect because the genital ulcers in LGV are typically painless and transient. Although buboes are seen in LGV, the painful ulcers in this case suggest another diagnosis.

 

Option C. Herpes genitalis: Incorrect because, although Herpes genitalis presents with painful ulcers, it usually does not involve painful inguinal buboes. Additionally, a history of recurrence might be mentioned, which is absent here.

 

Option D. Chancre (Syphilis): Incorrect because the ulcer in syphilis (chancre) is typically painless, and the lymphadenopathy is also painless.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chancroid should be suspected in a patient with painful genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes), especially in the absence of a history of recurrence and when syphilis and LGV have been ruled out based on the clinical presentation.

questions.text:
Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy should be given to which of the following persons?(INICET NOVEMBER 2022)

 

  1. Sharing the same clothes, towels
  2. Living with a patient with leprosy for > 6 month
  3. Contact of age more than 2 years
  4. Contact for more than 20 hours per week.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 3, 4

 

Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy should be given to contacts 2, 3 and 4.

 

Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy should be given to the following contacts:

 

  • Being identified as a contact, i.e., a person who has been in close contact with the index case for 20 hours (option 4) or more per week for more than 3 months (option 2) (Exception is blanket approach where no link with an index case needs to be established.)
  • Age: More than 2 years (option 3); if younger than 2 years, the child can be given SDR at the age of 2, in follow up visits of contacts (if meeting all other inclusion criteria.)
  • Consent of the contact obtained. Depending on the country situation, this can be written or a verbal consent. In case of children, consent should be obtained from the parent or guardian, and sometimes an assent from the grown-up children.
  • Sharing the same clothes and towels (Option 1), while a potential route of transmission, is not generally considered a primary criterion for chemoprophylaxis.

 

Exclusion criteria

 

  • Persons with possible signs and/or symptoms of leprosy;
  • Persons with possible signs and/or symptoms of TB or confirmed with TB;
  • Persons with a history of liver or kidney disorders;
  • Pregnancy; SDR can be given after the delivery;
  • Persons who have received rifampicin in the last two years e.g. as treatment of TB, leprosy or as prophylaxis (e.g. contact of another index case);
  • Persons with history of allergy to rifampicin;
  • Refusal to take SDR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy is crucial for contacts who have had significant exposure to an individual with leprosy, particularly those living in the same household or in close contact for extended periods.

 

Rifampicin:

 

  • A single dose of 600 mg kills more than 99% of the susceptible organisms present at the start of treatment, that is as much as 3 to 6 months of daily treatment with the combination dapsone plus Clofazimine.
  • Rifampicin has become established as a highly potent bactericidal drug, and it acts by inhibiting the bacterial DNA dependent RNA polymerase.
  • Single Dose of Rifampicin (SDR) is used in chemoprophylaxis.
  • Chemoprophylaxis must be initiated only 4 weeks after treatment for leprosy has begun in the patient so as to ensure the patient is non-infectious.

 

 

Ref - Jopling’s Handbook of Leprosy 6th Edition Page no 242

Leprosy/Hansen disease: Contact tracing and post-exposure prophylaxis

https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789290228073 (page 23, 24)

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3051288/

questions.text: In the case of a patient presenting with multiple nodulocystic lesions on the face, which drug is considered the preferred choice for treatment?(AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isotretinoin

 

This is a case of nodular acne. It comes under grade IV/severe acne.

 

Oral isotretinoin, an oral retinoid is indicated for the treatment of severe acne (nodular, acne conglobata & recalcitrant acne.

 

Recalcitrant acne is poorly responsive acne, with less than 50% improvement after 6 months of therapy with combined oral & topical antibiotics.

 

ACNE VULGARIS:

 

  • Most common form of acne.
  • Most characteristic lesion - Comedones.
  • Most severe form of acne vulgaris - Grade IV / Nodulocystic Acne.
  • Most severe form of acne - Acne conglobata.

 

Comedones (are considered as special lesions) are the specific lesions of acne vulgaris

 

Acne is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. Comedonal lesions are the Earliest lesions of acne. They represent the keratin plugs of the pilosebaceous duct.

 

When the keratin plug is inside the follicle, it is called a closed comedone or whitehead .

 

When the keratin plug is exposed to the environment, it gets oxidised by the air & turns black which is known as open comedone (blackhead)

 

Stages of acne

 

 

According to Global alliance algorithm for acne, Oral isotretinoin is indicated for the treatment of severe acne.

 

Global alliance algorithm for acne treatment

 

Image: global alliance algorithm for improving outcomes in acne

 

Global alliance algorithm for acne treatment:

 

 

 

BPO= Benzoyl peroxide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Steroids particularly corticosteroids, can reduce inflammation and are sometimes used to treat severe inflammatory conditions. However, systemic corticosteroids are generally not a first-line treatment for nodulocystic acne because of their potential side effects, including exacerbating acne upon withdrawal. Intralesional corticosteroids can be used for large, painful nodules but are not the primary treatment for widespread nodulocystic acne.

 

Option C. Erythromycin: It is an antibiotic that can be used to treat acne due to its antibacterial effects against Cutibacterium acnes (formerly Propionibacterium acnes), the bacteria partly responsible for acne. However, it is not as effective as isotretinoin for severe nodulocystic acne and is generally used for less severe forms or when other treatments are contraindicated.

 

Option D. Tetracycline: It is another class of antibiotics used in the treatment of acne. While tetracyclines can be effective for inflammatory acne, they are typically less effective than isotretinoin for severe nodulocystic acne and are not the preferred treatment in such cases.

 

Educational Objective::

 

Isotretinoin is the preferred treatment for severe nodulocystic acne due to its comprehensive action on reducing sebum production, decreasing inflammation, and normalizing keratinization.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 page no 90.7 & 90.37

questions.text: Identify the finding shown in the image below: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Herpes labialis

 

Explanation:

 

  • Herpes labialis, also known as a cold sore, is characterized by clusters of numerous grouped vesicles around the lips.
  • Recurrent herpetic lesions are very common & are vesicular and ulcerative and tend to occur in the same region.
  • Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) commonly and type 2 (HSV-2) rarely are responsible for its occurrence

 

Treatment: Foscarnet or cidofovir if acyclovir resistance develops in a patient with recurrent Herpes labialis. They act on viral DNA polymerases thus blocking DNA replication.

  • Oral acyclovir 200 mg and 5% topical acyclovir.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpangina or vesicular pharyngitis:

 

  • It is characterized by the presence of ulcerating small vesicles on the oral fauces and the posterior pharyngeal wall as seen in the below image.

 

 

  • Causative agent: Coxsackie virus. 

 

Option B. Molluscum contagiosum: Pearly white, wart-like umbilicated papules seen due to infection by Pox virus.

 

 

 

Option C. Impetigo: It is of 2 types:

 

  • Bullous – S. aureus
  • Non-bullous – S. aureus and Streptococcus. Golden-yellow or honey coloured crust seen.
     

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes labialis is identified as condition characterized by recurrent clusters of vesicles on the lips, caused by the herpes simplex virus, and distinguish it from other vesicular or pustular lesions such as herpangina, molluscum contagiosum, and impetigo.

 

References

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 25 Page no 25.12, 25.17-19, 25.20

Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology 9th edition Page no 2721

questions.text: What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Becker's naevus

 

The given image shows Becker's naevus.

 

  • The condition in question is an epidermal melanocytic nevus, characterized by the clustering of melanocytes in the epidermis.
  • It is commonly hairy and tends to appear during adolescence when there is heightened sensitivity to androgens, especially in areas like the outer arms, scapular region, and chest.

 

A triad of features can be seen:

 

  1. Hypertrichosis
  2. Acne
  3. Brownish Hyperpigmentation

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Becker's naevus is a patchy, hyperpigmented lesion that often develops during adolescence and may include hypertrichosis, distinguishing it from congenital conditions such as Mongolian spots, Naevus of Ito, and congenital melanocytic naevi.

 

 

Reference: Bolognia 4th edition, chapter 112, page no 2232

questions.text: A middle aged Indian male came to Derma OPD with the lesion as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma

 

  • The lesion in the image presents as a pearly nodule with telangiectatic vessels, which is characteristic of BCC.
  • This type of skin cancer most commonly occurs in sun-exposed areas, such as the face.
  •  The central ulceration and rolled borders are also indicative of BCC.
  • Given the appearance and the location on the face, BCC is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC):

 

  • SCC lesions typically present as scaly, erythematous plaques or nodules, often with a central area of ulceration.

 

 

  • They can also have a rough, sandpaper-like texture.
  • The lesion in the image does not exhibit the typical keratinized or scaly appearance that is suggestive of SCC.

 

Option C. Melanoma:

 

  • Melanoma usually presents with an asymmetrical shape, irregular borders, and multiple colors.

 

 

  • The lesion in the image does not demonstrate these features, making melanoma less likely.

 

Option D. Discoid Lupus Erythematous (DLE):

 

  • DLE often presents as erythematous, scaly plaques with atrophy and dyspigmentation, often affecting the face.

 

 

  • The lesion in the image does not show the scale or the degree of atrophy commonly seen with DLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize Basal Cell Carcinoma by its pearly appearance, telangiectasia, central ulceration, and rolled borders on sun-exposed skin.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 141.1-16, 142.1

Bailey & Loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 599, 604-605, 607-609, 611

questions.text: A female patient presented with a lesion as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Melanoma

 

Explanation:

 

The lesion shown in the image exhibits characteristics commonly associated with melanoma, which include:

 

  • Color variability: The lesion displays various shades of color, indicating the uneven distribution of melanin, which is a hallmark of melanoma.
  • Asymmetry: If the lesion is divided into four quadrants, the halves do not match, suggesting asymmetry, another key feature of melanoma.
  • Irregular borders: The borders of the lesion are not smooth or regular but rather irregular and jagged.
  • Diameter: The lesion is likely greater than 6 millimeters in diameter.
  • Evolution: There are changes in the lesion's appearance over time, including alterations in color, shape, and surface.

 

These features correspond to the "ABCDE" criteria used to identify potential melanomas:

 

  • Asymmetry
  • Border irregularity
  • Color variation
  • Diameter greater than 6 mm
  • Evolution over time

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Typically presents as a papulosquamous lesion rather than a pigmented one. It appears as a scaly, red, crusted nodule or plaque, often on sun-exposed areas.

 

Option C. Basal cell carcinoma: Usually manifests as a translucent nodule, surface telangiectasias and extensive local growth. Basal cell carcinoma lesions often have a rolled border and can ulcerate, forming what is known as a "rodent ulcer." They do not generally present with significant pigmentation or the described irregularities.

 

 

Option D. Seborrhoeic keratosis: Appears as a benign, well-demarcated, pigmented lesion with a "stuck-on" appearance. It typically has a uniform color and texture and lacks the irregular borders, asymmetry, and color variation seen in melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melanoma should be suspected in lesions that show asymmetry, border irregularity, color variation, diameter greater than 6 mm, and evolution over time. The "ABCDE" criteria are essential in identifying potential melanomas.
